questions.prompt: What is the view frustum in computer graphics?
options: The region of 3D space visible to the camera
questions.explanation: The view frustum is a truncated pyramid defining the visible region between the near and far clipping planes, bounded by the field of view.
Orthographic projection is a parallel projection that preserves parallel lines and does not apply perspective foreshortening, making objects the same size regardless of distance.

questions.prompt: In perspective projection, objects farther from the camera appear smaller.
questions.explanation: Perspective projection mimics human vision by applying foreshortening: objects farther away project to smaller sizes on the image plane, creating depth perception.

questions.prompt: What does the field of view (FOV) parameter control in perspective projection?
options: The angular extent of the visible scene
The distance to the near plane
questions.explanation: Field of view determines the angular width of the visible scene. A larger FOV shows more of the scene but with more distortion, like a wide-angle lens.

questions.prompt: Which coordinate system has the camera at the origin looking down the negative Z-axis?
questions.explanation: In view space (or camera space), the coordinate system is centered at the camera position, typically with the camera looking down the negative Z-axis by convention.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of the near clipping plane?
options: Prevent rendering objects too close to the camera
questions.explanation: The near clipping plane defines the closest distance at which objects are rendered. Objects closer than this are clipped, preventing numerical issues and unwanted extreme foreshortening.

questions.prompt: The aspect ratio is the ratio of viewport width to height.
questions.explanation: Aspect ratio is width divided by height, typically matching the display screen ratio (e.g., 16:9 or 4:3) to prevent distortion.

questions.prompt: What does the look-at transformation define?
options: Camera position, target point, and up vector
Field of view and aspect ratio
questions.explanation: The look-at transformation constructs the view matrix using the camera (eye) position, the target point to look at, and an up vector to define orientation.

questions.prompt: In normalized device coordinates (NDC), what is the typical range for x, y, and z?
options: [-1, 1] for x and y, [0, 1] for z
[0, width] for x, [0, height] for y
questions.explanation: In most graphics APIs (OpenGL convention), normalized device coordinates range from -1 to 1 for all three axes after perspective division (though some APIs use [0,1] for z).

questions.prompt: What transformation converts from view space to clip space?
questions.explanation: The projection matrix transforms coordinates from view/camera space to clip space, applying either perspective or orthographic projection based on the camera settings.

options: Divide x, y, z by w to get normalized device coordinates
Multiply coordinates by the projection matrix
Transform from world to view space
questions.explanation: Perspective division divides the homogeneous coordinates (x, y, z) by w to convert from clip space to normalized device coordinates, creating the perspective effect.

questions.prompt: Orthographic projection uses the same projection matrix as perspective projection.
questions.explanation: Orthographic and perspective projections use different matrices. Orthographic uses a simpler matrix without perspective division (w remains 1), while perspective modifies w based on z.

questions.prompt: Which type of projection is typically used for technical drawings and CAD applications?
questions.explanation: Orthographic projection is preferred for technical drawings because it preserves measurements and parallel lines, making it easier to interpret dimensions and angles.

questions.prompt: What is the vanishing point in perspective projection?
options: The point where parallel lines appear to converge
questions.explanation: Vanishing points are where parallel lines in 3D space appear to converge in the 2D projection, a key characteristic of perspective projection that creates depth perception.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of the far clipping plane?
options: Define the maximum visible distance from the camera
Prevent objects from getting too close
Control depth buffer precision near the camera
questions.explanation: The far clipping plane sets the maximum distance for rendering. Objects beyond this distance are clipped, helping manage depth buffer precision and rendering performance.
